author: @kannanlg4979
text: I don't understand why Indian companies are so much behind current salary and percentage increment based on that. The fact is that the new job has NOTHING to with previous role. Everyone needs to accept the fact that it's a new org with new clients, new use cases, new challenges and hence the salary should also be new (and not an update based on old one). Firstly the people applying for interview need to come out of this kind set. I see this is a motto set here. I have interviewed all around the world, you don't find this culture of comparing current and expected salaries anywhere else. Not but not the least, if a salary is confidential to the company, an employee disclosing it during the interview to someone in another company is a crime. So is the crime when HR asks for current CTC. All they need to worry about is the expected salary and if it falls within the budget. If it is within expectations, move ahead. People are not comfortable discussing their salary with their colleagues so how are they comfortable sharing it with someone in a different company - weird mind set.

author: @BharCode09
text: After having 10+ years of experience and was stuck with 15lpa salary in my previous job (at Oracle-SMTS), where my salary was never revised for 5 years, I took a break for an year to pursue something else (UPSC Exams). Then after experimenting and failing, with a career break of 1.2 years, I thought of getting back to s/f. Gave interviews and bagged 4 offers in 20-30 days, all were more than 100% hike. Just before the lockdown (March 2020). Highest offer was 40.5lpa, Amazon Bangalore (I knw that's not very high for Amazon). But joined IBM ISL, Bangalore for 37lpa, since I had location constraints. I'm not from any elite colleges like IITs or BITs. I'm a mother of 5yo. Trust me, for a women with career break, there is so much you have to face than a mere technical interview. But I didnt or never negotiate with HRs. I set my expectations and give interviews and what they think is better suited, they offer. And I usually either accept or reject without doing too much negotiation by showing other offers at hand. I NEVER get into diversity drives. I compete with generic skill set, like coding and Java stack and system design. Ready to learn any tech at any age. How many languages or tech skill you know, it doesn't matter. You should be ready to upgrade at any time.

author: @siddharth0401
text: I don't agree with you on this at all, first of all this 3 month's notice is absurd, companies who hv 3 month's notice don't want to wait for 3 months when it comes to their hiring, so it's turning employees into slaves and should go away, when in US people can go with 2 weeks notice whts so special in india, understand we don't hv  social security in india like the developed world incase the employer decides to fire but 3 month is definitely on the higher side, now on the ethical issue of ditching the employer who supposedly waited for u for 3 months, first of all employers hv multiple options they line would hv lined up as a fallback policy and also unless they really liked u or their actual requirement for the person is 6 months from now thy don't offer u in the first place if u hv more than 60 days notice, plus why shd the employee compromise on the quality of offer if they hv time in hand, it's not always about money or the CTC many other things are also there to be considered, and this is the only time an employee is in a stronger position in the employee employer relationship, it doesn't take much for any employer to fire anybody on any given day, I hv seen this many times, so it's in the best interest of the person to choose right to the best of their judgement at the time of entry and the best is not always by the CTC amount, things hv to be looked holistically
